newsitem.title: USA: Clinton encryption export proposal not ready yet.
newsitem.headline: Clinton encryption export proposal not ready yet.

text.p: The Clinton administration is not ready to release a widely anticipated proposal to relax export restrictions on computer encoding technology, a Commerce Department official said on Wednesday.
Undersecretary of Commerce William Reinsch, at a hearing of the House Judiciary Committee, said the proposal had not yet been formalized.
"Our work is not yet done," Reinsch said in prepared testimony. "We are continuing to consult with industry and international partners to refine our proposal."
The Judiciary Committee was holding a hearing on Resolution 3011, a bill that would dramatically relax encryption export limits.

Vice President Al Gore outlined the administration's ideas for relaxing limits on encryption exports in July, saying export controls should be liberalized only if encryption programs include so-called key escrow components.
The computer industry and many members of Congress oppose the key escrow and argue that foreign competitors will sell encryption programs without escrow features.
Reinsch said the key escrow approach is needed to help law enforcement and intelligence agencies deal with encryption.

"This approach balances economic needs with law enforcement concerns and is one that many of our major trading partners, most notably the United Kingdom, are also adopting," Reinsch said in his testimony.
He said the United States is working in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to craft a global policy for encryption.
